TypeSignature.Value: public abstract class UIBarItem : Foundation.NSObject, Foundation.INSCoding, IDisposable, UIKit.IUIAccessibilityIdentification, UIKit.IUIAppearance

.class public auto ansi abstract beforefieldinit UIBarItem extends Foundation.NSObject implements class Foundation.INSCoding, class ObjCRuntime.INativeObject, class System.IDisposable, class UIKit.IUIAccessibilityIdentification, class UIKit.IUIAppearance

Docs.summary: Base class for items added to the bars at the bottom of the screen.

remarks.para: Items that appear in the bar at the bottom of the screen act like s.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor() cil managed

Docs.summary: Default constructor that initializes a new instance of this class with no parameters.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(class Foundation.NSCoder coder) cil managed

Docs.summary: A constructor that initializes the object from the data stored in the unarchiver object.

remarks.para: This constructor is provided to allow the class to be initialized from an unarchiver (for example, during NIB deserialization). This is part of the protocol.

If developers want to create a subclass of this object and continue to support deserialization from an archive, they should implement a constructor with an identical signature: taking a single parameter of type and decorate it with the [Export("initWithCoder:"] attribute declaration.
The state of this object can also be serialized by using the companion method, EncodeTo.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(class Foundation.NSObjectFlag t) cil managed

Docs.summary: Constructor to call on derived classes to skip initialization and merely allocate the object.

remarks.para: This constructor should be called by derived classes when they completely construct the object in managed code and merely want the runtime to allocate and initialize the NSObject. This is required to implement the two-step initialization process that Objective-C uses, the first step is to perform the object allocation, the second step is to initialize the object. When developers invoke the constructor that takes the NSObjectFlag.Empty they take advantage of a direct path that goes all the way up to NSObject to merely allocate the object's memory and bind the Objective-C and C# objects together. The actual initialization of the object is up to the developer.

This constructor is typically used by the binding generator to allocate the object, but prevent the actual initialization to take place. Once the allocation has taken place, the constructor has to initialize the object. With constructors generated by the binding generator this means that it manually invokes one of the "init" methods to initialize the object.
It is the developer's responsibility to completely initialize the object if they chain up using the NSObjectFlag.Empty path.

In general, if the developer's constructor invokes the NSObjectFlag.Empty base implementation, then it should be calling an Objective-C init method. If this is not the case, developers should instead chain to the proper constructor in their class.

The argument value is ignored and merely ensures that the only code that is executed is the construction phase is the basic NSObject allocation and runtime type registration. Typically the chaining would look like this:

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyorassemblyhidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(native int handle) cil managed

Docs.summary: A constructor used when creating managed representations of unmanaged objects; Called by the runtime.

remarks.para: This constructor is invoked by the runtime infrastructure () to create a new managed representation for a pointer to an unmanaged Objective-C object. Developers should not invoke this method directly, instead they should call the GetNSObject method as it will prevent two instances of a managed object to point to the same native object.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance bool AccessibilityActivate() cil managed

Docs.summary: Activates accessibility for this UIView, returning on success.
Docs.remarks: This is a Boolean which will return a true value upon success.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual CoreGraphics.CGPoint AccessibilityActivationPoint { get; set; }

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the screen coordinates of the activation point for this element.
Docs.value: The default value is the center of the .
Docs.remarks: Application developers can set this value to move the location of the accessibility element. For instance, by default the of an app icon is the center of the icon, but during rearrangement, the point is moved to the "remove control" (the circled X).

Docs.summary: Notification constant for AnnouncementDidFinish
Docs.value: NSString constant, should be used as a token to NSNotificationCenter.

remarks.para: This constant can be used with the to register a listener for this notification. This is an NSString instead of a string, because these values can be used as tokens in some native libraries instead of being used purely for their actual string content. The 'notification' parameter to the callback contains extra information that is specific to the notification type.

Docs.summary: Gets the notification posted by an application that an announcement requires assistive technology.
Docs.value: To be added.

Docs.summary: Strongly-typed property that returns the UIAppearance class for this class.

remarks.para: Setting any appearance properties on this instance will affect the appearance of all instances of UIBarItem.
If developers want to control the appearance of subclasses of UIBarItem, they should use the method.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public static hidebysig class UIKit.UIBarItem/UIBarItemAppearance AppearanceWhenContainedIn(class System.Type[] containers) cil managed

Docs.param: List of types that developers want to have as the containers to apply this particular appearance
Docs.summary: Returns a strongly typed UIAppearance for instances of this class when the view is hosted in the specified hierarchy.
Docs.returns: The appearance proxy object that developers can use to set properties when the given container hierarchy is active

remarks.para: The returned object represents the UIAppearance proxy where developers can set appearance properties for instances of UIBarItem when those instances are contained in the hierarchy specified by the parameter.
If developers want to control the appearance of subclasses of UIBarItem, they should use the method.
The following example shows how the AppearanceWhenContainedIn method works

example.code: var mySliders = UISlider.AppearanceWhenContainedIn (typeof (UINavigationBar), typeof (UIPopoverController)); mySliders.TintColor = UIColor.Red;

remarks.para: For more information, see the documentation for the class.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void EncodeTo(class Foundation.NSCoder encoder) cil managed

Docs.param: The encoder object where the state of the object will be stored
Docs.summary: Encodes the state of the object on the provided encoder

remarks.para: This method is part of the protocol and is used by applications to preserve the state of the object into an archive.
Users will typically create a and then invoke the which will call into this method

If developers want to allow their object to be archived, they should override this method and store their state in using the provided parameter. In addition, developers should also implement a constructor that takes an NSCoder argument and is exported with [Export ("initWithCoder:")]

Docs.summary: A string constant used by accessibility APIs (see ) to identify the focused element.
Docs.value: To be added.

.method public static hidebysig class UIKit.UIBarItem/UIBarItemAppearance GetAppearance(class UIKit.UITraitCollection traits, class System.Type[] containers) cil managed

Docs.summary: Returns an appearance proxy for the specified .

MemberSignature.Value: public static UIKit.UIBarItem.UIBarItemAppearance GetAppearance<T> () where T : UIKit.UIBarItem;
.method public static hidebysig class UIKit.UIBarItem/UIBarItemAppearance GetAppearance<(class UIKit.UIBarItem) T>() cil managed

Docs.typeparam: The type for which the UIAppearance proxy must be returned. This is a subclass of UIBarItem.

summary.para: Obtains the appearance proxy for the subclass of UIBarItem.

returns.para: appearance proxy object for the specified type.

remarks.para: Setting any appearance properties on the returned object will affect the appearance of all classes and subclasses of the type parameter.
Unlike the property, or the method which only work on instances of this particular class, the proxies returned by GetAppearance can be used to change the style of subclasses.
The following example shows how the GetAppearance method works

example.code: var myTheme = UIBarItem.GetAppearance<MyUIBarItemSubclass> (); myTheme.TintColor = UIColor.Red;

remarks.para: For more information, see the documentation for the class.

MemberSignature.Value: public static UIKit.UIBarItem.UIBarItemAppearance GetAppearance<T> (UIKit.UITraitCollection traits) where T : UIKit.UIBarItem;
.method public static hidebysig class UIKit.UIBarItem/UIBarItemAppearance GetAppearance<(class UIKit.UIBarItem) T>(class UIKit.UITraitCollection traits) cil managed

Docs.typeparam: The type for which the UIAppearance proxy must be returned. This is a subclass of UIBarItem.

summary.para: Obtains the appearance proxy for the subclass of UIBarItem.

returns.para: appearance proxy object for the specified type.

remarks.para: The returned object represents the UIAppearance proxy where developers can set appearance properties for instances of UIBarItem.
Unlike the property, or the method which only work on instances of this particular class, the proxies returned by GetAppearance can be used to change the style of subclasses.
The following example shows how the GetAppearance method works

example.code: var myTheme = UIBarItem.GetAppearance<MyUIBarItemSubclass> (myTraits, ); myTheme.TintColor = UIColor.Red;

remarks.para: For more information, see the documentation for the class.

MemberSignature.Value: public static UIKit.UIBarItem.UIBarItemAppearance GetAppearance<T> (UIKit.UITraitCollection traits, Type[] containers) where T : UIKit.UIBarItem;
.method public static hidebysig class UIKit.UIBarItem/UIBarItemAppearance GetAppearance<(class UIKit.UIBarItem) T>(class UIKit.UITraitCollection traits, class System.Type[] containers) cil managed

Docs.typeparam: The type for which the UIAppearance proxy must be returned. This is a subclass of UIBarItem.
Docs.param: List of types that the developer wishes to have as the containers to apply this particular appearance.

summary.para: Obtains the appearance proxy for the subclass of UIBarItem that has the specified trait collection when the view is hosted in the specified hierarchy.

returns.para: appearance proxy object for the specified type.

remarks.para: The returned object represents the UIAppearance proxy where developers can set appearance properties for instances of UIBarItem that has the specified trait collection when the view is hosted in the specified hierarchy when those instances are contained in the hierarchy specified by the parameter.
Unlike the property, or the method which only work on instances of this particular class, the proxies returned by GetAppearance can be used to change the style of subclasses.
The following example shows how the GetAppearance method works

example.code: var myTheme = UIBarItem.GetAppearance<MyUIBarItemSubclass> (myTraits, typeof (UINavigationBar), typeof (UIPopoverController)); myTheme.TintColor = UIColor.Red;

remarks.para: For more information, see the documentation for the class.
